newsitem.title: USA: U.S. CREDIT OUTLOOK - Muted trade, short session.
newsitem.headline: U.S. CREDIT OUTLOOK - Muted trade, short session.

text.p: Little activity is expected in the U.S. government securities market Tuesday during an abbreviated Christmas Eve trading session.

The only potential market-moving statistical release will be the BTM/Schroders report on consumer spending at 0900 EST/1400 GMT, which investors will watch closely for hints at the strength of U.S. holiday season retail sales.
The Redbook Retail Sales Index also is slated for release, but not until 1455 EST/1955 GMT, well after the Treasury market's 1400 EST/1900 GMT early close.

"The only market mover could be the Mitsubishi index (as the BTM/Schroders index was formerly known)," said Elliott Platt, managing director of economic research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp.
"Investors will be looking for any information on how stores are doing," Platt said.
Even so, activity should remain muted.
"The trains were empty today (Monday), and by the time Johnson Redbook comes out (Tuesday), people will be on their way home," Platt added.
The Treasury Department will make its usual bill announcement, but that is not expected to create any reaction.
Another area of interest Tuesday likely will be prices in the energy complex, which fell Monday.

"People have been concerned about inflation in the energy complex and crude oil was down 50 cents or more Monday -- a factor contributing to some of the gains seen in bond prices," said Alan Levenson, economist at UBS Securities.
Nonetheless, the bulk of market participants' concerns will remain focused on consumer spending, Levenson added.
While thin trading activity can sometimes exaggerate market movements, few of the players who report for work Tuesday are expected to pay serious heed to any volatility.

Christopher Rupkey, vice president and financial economist at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, said the market likely will see some early activity following spending data in the morning, but then die down for the remainder of the session.
He saw a repeat of Monday's activity, characterized by an early spurt and then settling in quiet sideways trading the rest of the day.
Rupkey expected December sales to be up 4.0 percent to 4.5 percent from last year and consumer spending to have risen to about 3.0 percent in the fourth quarter, following a weak third quarter.
However, he discounted the effect prices in the energy sector may have on bond prices.
"The market's not really that focused on oil prices. It reacted little when they went up and I don't see much of a reaction should they go lower," he said.

Late Monday, the two-year note was 99-27/32, up 1/32, to yield 5.83 percent. The 10-year note was up 7/32 at 101-7/32, to yield 6.33 percent. The 30-year bond was at 99.00, up 12/32 to yield 6.58 percent.
The overnight bank lending or federal funds rate was due to open between 5-1/16 and 5-1/4 percent on Tuesday, traders said.
-- N.A. Treasury Desk, 212-859-1663
